text:
The video is super interesting, but somehow I fail to see how it can help to understand Keno's talk.
If I remember corectly, Keno was talking about cotangents, which I guess are related with the Homologies and Cohomologies, but I'm unable to see the direct link.

text:
cotangents and k-forms (at least for k=1) and differentials are the same thing; or depending in how you define them, are isomorphic.
That video explains k-forms. (and a bunch of other stuff)

text: The cotangent space of a smooth manifold is exactly the space of differential 1-forms.

elements.text: The cotangent space of a smooth manifold is exactly the space of differential 1-forms.

text: Answering my own question, the video I posted is missing the holes.

elements.text: Answering my own question, the video I posted is missing the holes.

text: The holes in the video are not really related to kenos talk. They are tangentially related in the sense that Kenos talk requires some understanding of something called a cotangent, which is a type of derivative on a manifold. Cotangents may be alternatively described as something called a 1-form. It just so happens that 1-forms are specific instances of a collection of objects called k-forms, which happen to be useful tools in the study of cohomology. Cohomology is a way of finding invariants— notably including, but certainly not limited to “holes”— of manifolds. The video is an introduction to the theory of cohomology and homology.

elements.text: The holes in the video are not really related to kenos talk. Cotangents may be alternatively described as something called a 1-form. It just so happens that 1-forms are specific instances of a collection of objects called k-forms, which happen to be useful tools in the study of cohomology. Cohomology is a way of finding invariants— notably including, but certainly not limited to “holes”— of manifolds. The video is an introduction to the theory of cohomology and homology.
